instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7105: What is R7105? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.5VS0_EN: What is 5VS0_EN? 5VS0_ EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I am not getting a green light on the charger but I am getting 16.7 on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3.37v on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.
<RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> is showing 0.48v on pin 1  and 1.4v on pin 2. There is suppose to be 5v on the VDD pins in order to turn on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>(<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>) so I troubleshooted to the <CHIP>U7190</CHIP> area since that is where <SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL> is created.

I replaced <CHIP>U7190</CHIP> with one from a donor board.

Here are some of the measurements I got from the <CHIP>U7190</CHIP> area.

<CHIP>U7190</CHIP> voltage | diode mode
pin 1 - 0.64v      0.688
pin 2 - 1.41v      0.003
pin 3 - 3.59v      0.361
pin 4 - 1.58v      0.004
pin 6 - 13.55v    0.56
pin 7 - shows 5v even though the schematic says it's a NC.

I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7195</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7195</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7196</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7198</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C7199</CAPACITOR> with new parts from mouser. For some reason <RESISTOR>R7195</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7196</RESISTOR> both measure 155kohms even though they measured the proper resistance before I put them on the board. Is there something that could pull the resistance down?

I get a short to ground on both sides of L7195 and when I remove it and check for the short on the pads I get a short only on the Pin 2 side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Id say <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is dead for sure. Also check <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> and the current sense circuits.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Also <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> measured proper resistance. <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> showed 13.5v on one side and 10.8v on the other in voltage mode.  the current sense resistors(<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR>) weren't measuring properly so I just replaced them but that didnt solve the issue.

So <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is what could be bringing the voltage down from <SIGNAL>PP5V1_SW</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7190</CHIP>? I didn't know that was possible since it is separate diagram from the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> circuit on the schematic. Nice to know. I'll try replacing it later on tonight.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <CHIP>U7190</CHIP> powers the 5V to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> so yes it can pull it down. You need to check the resistors again as a shorted <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> could have burned them again. First replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> then the resistors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Okay. I replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and now I get a green light on charger and 15.5v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>(though schematic says it should be 8.6v).

I checked most of the power rails and these are the ones that were missing.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.08v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> - 0.08
<SIGNAL>PP0V675_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> - 0.002
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> - 0.079
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - .022
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_SW_TBTBST</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBTLC</SIGNAL> - 3.3v

I couldn't find which chip creates <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> but I did see <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> comes from <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> and I was only getting 3.31v on <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>(turns <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> on) and 5v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>. Should I be troubleshooting <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>?

Worth noting: When I first had this board 6 months I was just starting and I was testing the board w/o the heatsink on and the cpu would get hot so hopefully I didn't kill the cpu. Also, when probing around I caused <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> to spark and it has a burn on the top of the chip.
I also see a tiny bit of blue corrosion next to <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> so I don't know if that could be causing any issues here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: How can the CPU get hot if it doesn't even turn on? Yes corrosion anywhere can cause problems. A hole in the chip would of course mean it is dead. This board sound like a hell hole.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
There is a slight misunderstanding.
The CPU doesn't turn on at all now but when I first got this board months ago it was working & getting hot and I was getting a fan spin but I wasn't getting anything to appear on the screen. 
Then while trying to troubleshoot display issues I caused a spark things started messing up and I was getting no light on the charger or fan spin. 

I will replace the burned <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> chip and start troubleshooting. Where should I start looking in order to get <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> working?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> has nothing to do with the board working, you can remove it once the boards powers up we'll get to that one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Okay.
<SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> is showing 3.31v which is a problem. Should I check <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> to figure why its 3.31v and not 5v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Why would an enable signal be 5V, it's a logic signal and is normally 3.3V. If <SIGNAL>5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> is there then all other S0 voltages should be there and you should move on the check if CPU Vcore is there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Sorry. I thought since the title had 5V in it that it should be 5v.

Anyways, I checked <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and got 0.022v.

If I have 0.08v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> how is <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> going to turn on in order to make <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I got 0.111v on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. I also measured on <RESISTOR>R8162</RESISTOR> and got 0.003 on pin 1 and 0.111v on pin 2. Also there is no resistor on <RESISTOR>R8162</RESISTOR> as well as on my 3 donor boards but the schematic doesn't say that it is a no-stuff.

Could you explain to me what <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> does in the circuit? Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What is on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> shows 3.33v as well as <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Well, some voltage is missing. If S4 and S3 are there then everything should come on, besides CPU Vcore. Find the one that is missing, measure voltage on all coils first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 2029"]Well, some voltage is missing. If S4 and S3 are there then everything should come on, besides CPU Vcore. Find the one that is missing, measure voltage on all coils first.[/QUOTE]
When you say measure voltage on all coils which coils are you referring to?
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is the rail that is missing. All the other s0 rails are present.
Is <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> the chip that creates <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>? If so, should I try replacing that chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What voltage do you have on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL>? If you have nothing and have 5V on pin 1-3 and 3V on pin 2 from <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> could be a bad <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> or a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> line..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I get 0.08v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>.
On <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> I got 5.147v on pins 1/3. 3.31v on pin 2.
I have the very thin fluke probes but I cant fit it inside on the <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> pin for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> to check for a short. Is there any other way I can check for a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL>.

Also, when I insert a usb stick and power on the board the usb stick lights up. I don't know if that adds to anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Pads for <RESISTOR>R5530</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5530</RESISTOR> is not present but pin 1 and 2 are shorted on the board, here is where <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> becomes <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>.........

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I got a short to ground on pins 1 and 2 of <RESISTOR>R5530</RESISTOR>. Where should I go next in order to find the problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Apply 0.5V with power supply on that rail without limit current and feel what is getting hot, you can use the alcohol trick... If you don't see/feel anything go up on voltage little by little....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I can take a guess that <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> is dead. You have 5V coming in and enable is high and the output is shorted. <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> is probably getting hot too.
I assume you already removed the fried <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Wow I left the fried <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> on the board the whole time and once I removed it the short was gone <RESISTOR>R5530</RESISTOR> and when I plugged the charger in the fan spun and the cpu gets warm.

When I removed <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> the pads for pins 9 and 10 were burned and came off.
Now I need to run a wire but I have never done this before. I have some very thin wire that was from a lvds cable. Can I just use a piece for each pad and put one side of the wire on the pad and solder the other side to the probe points that are next to it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The CPU gets warm but does the board work? You should have an image without backlight now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I plugged the board into the computer as well as KB,TP, speakers but I don't get anything on the screen as well as no chime and no questionmark folder when i use a flashlight. When I checked <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> i got somewhere around 1.74v and <SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL> showed 15v.

I tried many scenarios to see if one of the cables might be causing this. I tried with & w/o the keyboard, trackpad, and display cable.
I used my thunderbolt to hdmi cable port, the hdmi cable in the hdmi port and that still didnt show and I also tried with the ssd plugged in.

Before this computer stopped working part of the screen would show lines going through and was messed up. I also believe the trackpad wasn't working but ill have to check with the owner about it.

I did all this with the battery unplugged because when I plug the battery in the charger just keeps flashing a green light and the fan never spins and nothing happens.

Also, I haven't put another chip on <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> yet. I wanted to know where do I run the wire to for pins 9/10.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Use boardview and press "N" and write the name of pin 9 (<SIGNAL>ISNS_LCDBKLT_N</SIGNAL>), this will show you all the point where this "NET" goes, choose the closest one, in this case probe 541.... Same for pin 10....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Okay I ran the wires to there points and put the chip on top. I get a short to ground in diode mode on both of the wires I ran but when I measure pins 3 and 4 of <RESISTOR>R7700</RESISTOR> I get 15.75v so I don't know if the wires I ran are good.
Anyways I tried once again to turn the computer on and I still see nothing with a flashlight or with hdmi on tv. <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> shows 3.37v so that isn't the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I checked all the power rails and they are all present except the thunderbolt rails are no longer there which is why thunderbolt to hdmi wasnt working.

I fixed the wires I ran on <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and they are no longer shorting to ground.
I've been trying to troubleshoot backlight on <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> so hopefully I can see the screen is working. I am getting 15v on pin 3 and 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>. The voltage dividers <RESISTOR>R7701</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7702</RESISTOR> both measured the proper resistance and pin 11 of <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> is not shorted to ground. I'm more familiar with the backlight circuit on the MBA than with these MBP retina's. Should I try replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>?

Any thoughts/ideas [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] [USER="1"]larossmann[/USER] [USER="36"]aprendiz[/USER] ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: IS the board even working? You are worrying about the backlight while there is no chime. Plug in an USB mouse and see if it lights up, of not the board is not even working....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes. When I plug a usb stick in it lights up. I also get a fan spin and the cpu gets warm and <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> measures 1.74v. All the main power rails are there except for thunderbolt.

Does a USB mouse light up was the question. Who knows what the light on the USB stick is for, it should probably blink if there is activity...
MOUSE!

When you test for that what does it tell you about a board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: First you need at least an image on the LCD. Got 5V on L8300?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
L8300 would fluctuate but the most I saw on it was 0.18v. I checked <RESISTOR>R8319</RESISTOR> as well and it showed 0.1v and would also fluctuate. The resistance measured the proper 1k.

Also on Pin 1 of J8300(<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>) I get around 9v immediately after I plug the charger in and it quickly goes down towards 0v. I got 0v on <SIGNAL>LCD_PSR_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL>.
Does that mean that the board is not seeing the screen. When the computer was working the right side of the screen was showing lines through it so that could be the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is this an issue where the screen isn't being recognized?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You now first need to verify if the LCD is at least working. Try it on another machine of the same type. You can also connect an external LCD to the thunderbolt port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Dang. I don't have another retina mbp.
how can I connect an external lcd to thunderbolt? I tried connecting the computer to my tv with a thunderbolt to hdmi adapter i have but that didn't work since the <SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL> and the other TBT rails aren't present anymore. It was present before I replaced that burned <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have no idea any more. If you cannot rule out a defective LCD you can mess with the board all you want it is not going to work. This problem could now be the board or the LCD

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Okay. Hopefully I can restore the thunderbolt rails so I can at least know that works. I am not getting <SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL> and I traced that back to <TRANSISTOR>Q3005</TRANSISTOR>. I am not getting anything on <SIGNAL>TBT_A_HV_EN</SIGNAL> and that signal comes from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> which is covered with a shield.

Do you know what signal turns on the <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> because maybe that is missing?
